comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: In the 1901 census, I think William A. Dobbyn, 34, CoI, and his wife and family are living in the house. [EDIT: I don't think so anymore, see below for (Mary) Hilda Dobbyn] If we check the 1901 census for married females named Davis in Waterford who are CoI, we find only Alice Davis, 23, who has children aged 1 and 0, hence was probably married in 1899-1900.

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content:
From ancestry.com, Ireland, Births and Baptisms, 1620-1911:
Joseph Dobbyn b 24 Mar 1876, son of Joseph and Mary Dobbyn at Leoville, Waterford Mary Dobbyn b 22 Aug 1870 daughter of Joseph Dobbyn and Mary Josephine Dobbyn at Waterford Mary Hilda Dobbyn, b 28 Aug 1878 daughter of Joseph Butler Dobbyn and Mary Josephine Dobbyn
Ireland, Civil Registration Deaths Index, 1864-1958
Mary Josephine Dobbyn b: abt 1843 d Dec 1878 - Waterford
I'm not sure how these relate to the ladies in the picture.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content:
BOATING ACCIDENT The Waterford crew which competed at the New Ross regatta, on Thursday, had a very narrow escape from drowning. The boat, a tub pair, capsized, throwing its occupants - Messrs. Dobbyn, Mosley, and Farrell (cox) - into the water. Mr. Mosley, who cannot swim, caught hold of the keel of the boat with one hand after it had turned over, and with the other grasped young Farrell, who also is unable to swim, and held him over water. Ultimately the immersed crew were rescued in a most exhausted condition; were it not for the great strength and pluck of Mr. Mosley, both he and the youthful coxswain would undoubtedly have been drowned. Nenagh Guardian - Wednesday, 1 September 1886
This Dobbyn is noted in many rowing reports from 1886-ish as W.A., so he's presumably [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley]'s William A. Dobbyn? He was a definite member of Waterford Boat Club, sometimes rowing Stroke. Wonder if he's in this one?
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

Helen Gabrielle Dobbyn , b 26 Mar 1877 daughter of Joseph Dobbyn and Mary Josephine Dobbyn at Waterford

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: By 1906, I think Leoville was occupied by a Mr. A.S. McCoy, solicitor. This 1913 .pdf lists him there, and William Dobbyn in Newtown. The 1911 census shows McCoy living in Grange, Upper, Part of (Rural), a good description of Leoville's location at the time . The 1901 census has him on John's hill, and the DIA says Leoville had alterations in 1906 for a Mr. McCoy.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] You're dead right! The NIAH lists Grange Upper as the townland.

A "Dobbyn and McCoy" appeared before the Hon Judge Miller in the Court of Bankruptcy in March 1897. Very arcane description, so I can't make out why they were there - bankrupt, witnesses, Mr McCoy in his capacity as a solicitor...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: Untimely Death Klaxon "William Augustus Nelson Dobbyn, son of WIlliam Alexander Dobbyn, of RIverside, Waterford, and Eleanor Alelaide, b 9 Jun 1896, ... was accidentally killed at Beauval 4 Jan 1917, by the bursting of a Mills' grenade in the hand of one of his men, while instructing a bombing class" The family tree on which I found his obit has father William A Dobbyn's dates as 1866-1956.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: Aha! In 1901, in Waterford Rural, Cove (a DED next door to Grange Upper), in a house of 12 rooms, we find one solitary Dobbyn: Hilda Dobbyn, 23, Head of Family, Roman Catholic? There are no 12 room houses in the DED called Cove in 1911, so I think this may be Leoville.

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] The shorthand used in giving notice in bankruptcy hearings is - name of bankrupt, staeg of bankruptcy proceedings, name of whoever is representing the bankrupt.

AT times it was Dobbyn and Tandy, at others it was Dobbyn, Tandy, McCoy, and later on Dobbyn & McCoy.

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: The William A family tree shows WIlliam A and Eleanor having 5 sons and 2 daughters. The daughters were born in 1904 and 1910, so that puts them out well of the running as candidates for this photo.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content:
This 1901 Hilda Dobbyn was born in 1878, so is very likely [http://www.flickr.com/photos/johnspooner]'s Mary Hilda Dobbyn, b 28 Aug 1878 daughter of Joseph Butler Dobbyn and Mary Josephine Dobbyn.

This photo cannot be 1880 if she is one of these ladies, it surely must be 1890 at least?

And that would mean the older lady is likely Mary Josephine Dobbyn (explaining why her daughter goes by Hilda...) [EDIT] No, no, Mary Josephine Dobbyn died in 1878, before Hilda was 1 year old. Plus this lady is not wearing a wedding ring.

comment.author: 30369211@N00

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: The Important Question - spectacles or pince-nez?

comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content:
Pince-nez or spectacles. A tricky choice, but the Aberdeen Weekly Journal, Wednesday, August 25, 1880 was on hand with advice in an article entitled 'Ladies and Spectacles', from which this is an extract:
When women dislike each other they have a method of staring at one another through their spectacles which conveys more meaning than it would be possible for language to express. Glasses rarely increase the benignity of the countenance, but women can look through spectacles with a disagreeable expression which is beyond the power of the male sex. We have observed that many short-sighted ladies who never use glasses before men , make unblushing use of the most uncompromising spectacles when they are, or imagine themselves to be, exclusively in the company of their own sex. At any rate they will often use an eye-glass or pince-nez in general society, but wear regular spectacles amongst women. The pince-nez has become wonderfully fashionable of late years. If you place one alongside of a pair of spectacles on a table both appear equally harmless, but upon the nose the effect is extraordinary. It is amusing to meet a person whom one is accustomed to see in regular spectacles wearing pince-nez for the first time. You hardly recognise your friend. The face looks half-clothed, and it wears a rollicking expression which is in strong contrast to the sobriety of its old spectacled days.

comment.author: 33577523@N08
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley/] Yes Dobbyn & McCoy are still in business, I'm a client of theirs at the moment. Carol the Cove shop was close by, a favourite place to buy sweets when we were children, always loved the front of the building, its now an off license I believe, the Cove Bar is still there next door. Another great Poole photo by the way.

Love the ornate cording on the seated young lady's dress. And the watered silk of the older one.
